newsitem.title: USA: St. Jude says focused on integration.
newsitem.headline: St. Jude says focused on integration.

text.p: St. Jude Medical Inc said it is concentrating on integration activities, including training its sales force to sell implantable defibrillators, or ICDs, made by Ventritex Inc, which was acquired in May.

"We are now in the integration, execution and growth stage of our cardiac rhythm management strategy," said chief executive Ronald Matricaria in a statement that accompanied release of the company's second-quarter results.
Net sales for the second quarter increased 19 percent to $261 million from $220 million in the second quarter of 1996.

Excluding several special items, St. Jude said second-quarter earnings totalled $0.36 per share, up from $0.32 per share a year ago. Including all special items, the company earned $0.09 per share on the most recent quarter.
St. Jude shares closed Wednesday up 1-3/16 at 40-13/16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The company reported that second-quarter 1997 net sales by division were as follows: heart valve disease management $75 million (up nine percent), cardiac rhythm management $169 million (up 17 percent), interventional cardiology $9 million (up 11 percent) and other $8 million.

After making the complex and long-awaited $365 million purchase of Ventritex, St. Jude is preparing to unleash its 400-person sales team with Ventritex's ICDs in a bid to become a strong third competitor in the ICD field.
The fast-growing market for ICDs -- small electronic devices implanted in the body and wired to the heart to keep it from beating too fast -- is dominated by Medtronic Inc and Guidant Corp.

"The combination of Ventritex's ICD and pacing products along with Daig's fast-growing electrophysiology and clinical-stage atrial fibrillation products and Pacesetter's pacemaker systems, gives our CRM business one of the broadest product offerings in the industry and essentially completes this technology platform," Matricaria said.
St. Jude acquired Daig Corp in mid-1996.
